Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 09:52AM Laura-Vic wrote: Oh I can relate ... it was one of the only GOOD side effects that I actually was looking forward to. My period stopped after the 3rd round of chemo. I haven't had my period all year ... ha !! and just finished my last cocktail the end of February. I do not want it back ... can you ladies arrange that - ha !!! It has been so very nice not to have Aunt Flo around ... I'm 48 years old and keeping my fingers crossed that it is permanent. Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: Menstral Cycle? joykeeperorg wandralong

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 09:10AM Laura-Vic wrote: Nothing like a little furry person curled up on your lap needing pats and hugs and purrringgg.... Absolutely the pet(s) can stay ... all their fur and stuff - your body is used to it. I live alone and had no choice but to deal with the litter box. As folks have said - a mask helps and wash your hands, wash your hands, wash your hands. My oncologist had absolutely no issue with my 2 cats ... they are good buddies and were a constant in my crazy world of appointments, meds and feeling tired. In fact, I think they enjoyed their "mom" being home with them more often !! They got extra spoiled and loved it !! They also seemed to know when I needed them to be more lovey ... animals have an amazing ability to know when their humans need some attention. so - grab their ball ... keep their treats stocked ... absolutely, the furry people stay !!! Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: pets and chemo haykat57 mittmott

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 07:01PM Laura-Vic wrote: Tina - I developed a blood clot during chemo / post surgery (bilateral mastectomy). My clot is higher than yours, closer to the groin area. I too am on Warfrin (Cummadin) ... blood tests to check my INR twice per week while I continue chemo. It's a real pain and my veins look like a bad drug user - especially since they can only use my one arm. Yes, my oncologist has said that the Warfrin will be a reality for at LEAST the six month period and over the coming year she will attempt to get it gone ... but ... the clot is a reality and cannot monkey with it. At the end of my chemo (luckily, this month) she will try to get the blood tests down to weekly and then increase the timeframe as long as the INR is okay. And yes - I do bruise more easily and chemo has destroyed those lovely nose hairs so, nose bleeds are also something you'll need to watch if you're doing chemo. She explained that blood clots do not reabsorb or go away ... they can become smaller should small bits break away but to think of it as a sponge that we are trying to put pencil holes into. We want the pencil holes because then the blood flows easily and will not be a problem. We do not want the sponge to be full because then the risk of breakage and moving into the lungs (for example) is real ... and that can be lethal. So ... continue on with Warfrin and INR rates ...another gift of cancer .... Take care - that's my experience. Looking forward to being wiened off ... Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: Blood clot in leg post BM& sentinel node exc with expanders Laurie4507 jdg1

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 09:06PM Laura-Vic wrote: Hi there ... yeh, don't "look" for side effects - everyone is different. While I had a different cocktail then you - I am in my 5th of 6 chemo treatments. In general ... I'm good for the first few days and then oh, about day 4-7 I'm a tad crappy ... meaning more tired, inability to focus ... have what my friends refer to as "that starried eyed look". I have been fortunate - limited nausea (nothing that some deep breathing and the meds couldn't deal with - ha !). Like others have said - do not suffer in silence - let folks know what's going on - most times, it can be addressed and/or others of us have been there and can chime in on what we might have done. Yes, I too had the heartburn - oh my. I got put on Nexium - was a blessing, wish I had spoken earlier. And you are on the right track with the water ... my body just seemed to scream for more water - it is important to flush your system of the chemo and push it through ... so, keep on drinking, it's great for you. The other thing is protein - eggs and such. Got to keep your body strong and the white cells strong. I was told that between day 10 and day 18 is the lowest white cell count so be especially cognizant not to be around folks who may be fighting any viruses or such - your body may be more vulnerable. Your best guide is you .. your body will tell you - rest, drink or whatever. Let your oncologist know of any "glitches" and do as they tell you ... Chemo is, in my experience, not the stuff of the nightmares we may have imagined. It is do'able and I have every faith that you too can do it ... we're in this together and it can be done ... we will do it. Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: question about chemo bean4865 Laura-Vic

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 11:25PM Laura-Vic wrote: Sandy - you are singing my song !!!  I finished my tx in May, 2008 ... and guess what, in September - 2 new lumps!!!  Yup, and off to the mammo and u/s I went.  Let me cut to the chase - NOT CANCER.  One of the lumps was scar tissue where the breast removal (I had a bilateral) had healed with fiberous tisue.  The second lump was a seroma - and, has now been drained.  They tell me it can recurr - oh great.  Anyways ... just wanted to drop you a quick note to say YES YES it happened to me.  I know you had your biopsy today and may be worried.  I know to say don't worry is useless, but hear me girl ... it happened to me too and NO CANCER !!! Fingers crossed that you have the same outcome.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 07:21AM Laura-Vic wrote: Bonnie - I don't have any tricks but I second your thoughts ... I don't find things taste bad particularly, they simply have no taste - kinda like eating cardboard. The only things that have taste are spicy and they hurt / burn my mouth. I didn't have taxotere - I'm on something called docetaxol. I think all the chemo cocktails have similar side effects. I've done the mouthwashes and such - no impact on food being any more tasty and thus, any more desirable. Let's see if anyone with more experience has some good ideas. Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: I Want My Tastebuds Back Bonnielv licorice2006

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 02:08PM Laura-Vic wrote: Lovemygarden - you hit the BINGO and I did laugh.  Although - I was a heavy chested person (48DDD).  I think my friends thought I'd react badly to zero boobs (had bilateral in Sept 2007), there was surprisingly zero reaction.  My surgeon tucked a little tisuse in a flap formation - in his words "so if you do wanna wear a bra, it won't slap ya in the face".  hahahaha  Work colleagues now shake their head - ya ya, shut up about you're not wearing boobs.  I don't have to adjust my bra, I don't have gapping in my blouse, I don't sweat in the summer and I'll never have boobs looking at dust bunnies.  I can purchase whatever tops I want and I do not have to wear a camosole if I don't feel like it.  The freedom is oddly happy.  Realizing that I'm 51 years old now probably also plays a part.  My boobs do not define my being female - my head did that years ago - haha.  I have prosthetics and depending on what I'm wearing, yes, I wear them.  But - it's a choice.  Gee - I love choices!!! Everyone makes their own decisions and have multiple reasons why .... I am only sharing that at this point anyways - no desire to have more surgery or more thinking about feeling for lumps.  OOOO - excuse me while I do not have to adjust straps or elastic - hahaha.
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 10:12PM Laura-Vic wrote: Hi Susan- that's on my mind too. While I am only 4 weeks out of my last chemo, and, I never thought hair would be an important issue - it has become important now that I want to look more like "I'm done". I'm sure each chemo cocktail is different but geez - give us some hair back !! I even really miss my nose hair - I'm tired of being such close buddies with the Kleenex company. I too have no eyelashes and no eyebrows. My head hair is maybe best described as dryer lint. So, basically - I'm still bald. My hair is so very fine, and very light .. you cannot see anything. I'd like my leg and armpit hair to stay away permanently though!!! Now - that would be nice. Let's hope that it returns wavy, dark and thick !! On my head I mean !!! Ha ... Laura in Victoria
Posts.Title: Hair coming back and eyelashes? SusanB12 smithlme

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 04:23PM Laura-Vic wrote: Hi Deborah -  I'm laughing with you - trust me !!!  My friends wanted to celebrate the finish of chemo like is was some great accomplishment (and it was) but I wanted to cry.  I used to describe it like a black hole - being in a row boat with just one oar - going around and around in circles with no plan.  Funny to say - but I'm jealous of you.  I am triple negative and there is no pill, no nothing for me to take at the end.  For me it was "you're done, good luck".  What the heck ???  For almost a year of my life, everyone wanted to know everything about every bodily function and now you're just sending me out the door with your best wishes ????  So as these ladies have said - welcome to the What the Heck Club??  And if someone else told me how good I was looking - geeeezzzz !!!  Look inside - not such a pretty picture.   I was the rock through surgery, chemo and radiation.  I joked, I made "the best of it" -- whatever you want to say.  At the end - basket case.  I think I finally had to accept what I had just been through - and more importantly - why.  My life had been on hold - I HAD cancer.  But there you go - I HAD cancer ... cancer did not have me!!!  I was sick, food tasted like cardboard or dryer lint, my hair fell out, my neuropathy ached, my finger nails and toe nails were gone ... but the treatment was for those words:  HAD cancer.  You too - HAD cancer.  Now ... you are in the rebuilding your body, giving it some additional umph (eg., tamoxifen) and trying to find that second oar for that friggin boat - ha ha.  Honest, most days I am now good (11 months post tx) but some days for no apparent reason, basket case again.  But I give myself permission ... heck, if I can beat cancer what's a little investment in the Kleenex company?? I'm not really a reader ... but there was a book that hit all the buttons for me.  It is called "Dancing in Limbo - Making Sense of Life After Cancer."  It is by Glenna Halvorson-Boyd and Lisa K. Hunter, both of whom are cancer survivors.  It is written in "real" language and tells all those stories that girlfriends share.  Anyways, your local library will have it ... it's easy reading and I just couldn't put it down.  In fact - I got it out for the 2nd time not long ago. So ... one foot infront of the other.  Crazy?  well ... I don't know you well enough - ha ha, but if you're in this group - we are all crazy and that's what's got us through it !!! Celebrate crazy - way less pressure !!!
Posts.Title: Call me crazy... cherneski jenn3
